q: What are the symptoms of a urinary tract infection (UTI)?
a: Symptoms of a urinary tract infection (UTI) may include pain or a burning sensation when peeing, needing to pee more often than usual, needing to pee suddenly or more urgently than usual, and pee that looks cloudy or has blood in it.

q: When should I see a GP for a possible urinary tract infection (UTI)?
a: You should see a GP if you have symptoms of a urinary tract infection for the first time, your symptoms get worse or do not improve within 2 days, or your symptoms come back after treatment.

q: What should I do if I think I have a urinary tract infection (UTI) and have severe symptoms?
a: If you think you have a urinary tract infection (UTI) and have a very high temperature, feel hot and shivery, have confusion or drowsiness, or see blood in your pee, you should ask for an urgent GP appointment or get help from NHS 111.

q: What treatments can a GP provide for a urinary tract infection (UTI)?
a: If a GP thinks you have a urinary tract infection (UTI), they may offer self-care advice, prescribe a short course of antibiotics, or suggest waiting 48 hours before taking antibiotics in case your symptoms improve on their own.

q: How can recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs) be treated?
a: If you have recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs), a GP may prescribe a different antibiotic, a low-dose antibiotic for up to 6 months, or a vaginal cream containing estrogen. They may also refer you to a specialist for further tests and treatments.

q: What should I do if I still have symptoms after being treated for a urinary tract infection (UTI)?
a: If you still have symptoms after being treated for a urinary tract infection (UTI), you should speak to your GP about chronic UTIs. They may refer you to a specialist for further evaluation and treatment.

q: What can I do to ease the symptoms of a urinary tract infection (UTI)?
a: To help ease the symptoms of a urinary tract infection (UTI), you can take paracetamol to reduce pain and a high temperature. Rest, drink plenty of fluids, and avoid having sex. Some people may also try cystitis sachets or cranberry products, although there is no evidence they help with UTIs.

q: What are the causes of urinary tract infections (UTIs)?
a: Urinary tract infections (UTIs) are usually caused by bacteria from stool entering the urinary tract through the urethra. Factors that increase the risk of UTIs include having sex, pregnancy, urinary catheters, and conditions that block or make it difficult to empty the bladder.

q: How can I prevent urinary tract infections (UTIs)?
a: To prevent UTIs, you should wipe from front to back after using the toilet, keep the genital area clean and dry, drink plenty of fluids, pee after sex, and promptly change soiled nappies or incontinence pads. Avoid using scented soap, holding in your pee, rushing when going to the toilet, wearing tight synthetic underwear, and consuming lots of sugary or alcoholic drinks.

q: What are some additional ways to prevent recurrent UTIs?
a: If you experience recurrent UTIs, some evidence suggests taking D-mannose or cranberry products on a daily basis may be helpful. However, speak to your doctor before taking these during pregnancy, and be aware that they can contain a lot of sugar. If you're taking warfarin, you should avoid cranberry products.

q: What are the symptoms of a urinary tract infection (UTI)?
a: Symptoms of a UTI may include pain or a burning sensation when peeing (dysuria), needing to pee more often than usual, needing to pee suddenly or more urgently than usual, cloudy urine, and lower tummy pain or pain in the back just below the ribs.

q: When should I see a GP if I have symptoms of a UTI?
a: You should see a GP if you have symptoms of a UTI for the first time, if you're a man with UTI symptoms, if you're pregnant and have UTI symptoms, if you're caring for an older, frail person who may have UTI symptoms, if you have symptoms of UTI after surgery, or if your symptoms get worse or do not improve within 2 days.

q: What should I do if I think I have a kidney infection?
a: If you think you have a kidney infection, you should ask for an urgent GP appointment or get help from NHS 111 if you have a very high temperature, feel hot and shivery, have a very low temperature below 36C, are confused or drowsy, or can see blood in your urine.

q: What treatments can I expect from a GP for a UTI?
a: A GP may offer self-care advice, recommend taking a painkiller, prescribe a short course of antibiotics, or prescribe antibiotics but suggest waiting for 48 hours before taking them to see if symptoms improve on their own.

q: What treatments are available for recurrent UTIs?
a: If you have recurrent UTIs, a GP may prescribe a different antibiotic, prescribe a low-dose antibiotic for up to 6 months, prescribe a vaginal cream containing estrogen if you've gone through menopause, or refer you to a specialist for further tests and treatments.

q: What should I do if I still have UTI symptoms after treatment?
a: If you still have UTI symptoms after treatment, you should speak to your GP about chronic UTIs and ask to be referred to a specialist.

q: What can I do to ease the symptoms of a UTI?
a: To help ease UTI symptoms, you can take paracetamol to reduce pain and a high temperature, rest and drink enough fluids to pass pale urine regularly during the day, and avoid having sex. Some people may also try cystitis sachets or cranberry drinks and products, although there's no evidence they help treat a UTI once the infection has started.

q: What are the causes of UTIs?
a: UTIs are usually caused by bacteria from feces entering the urinary tract. The bacteria enter through the urethra, which is why women are more likely to get UTIs due to having a shorter urethra.

q: How can I prevent UTIs?
a: To prevent UTIs, you can wipe from front to back after going to the toilet, keep the genital area clean and dry, drink plenty of fluids, pee as soon as possible after sex, and promptly change nappies or incontinence pads if soiled. It's also important to avoid using scented soap, holding in pee when you feel the urge to go, rushing when going to the toilet, wearing tight synthetic underwear, and having excessive alcoholic drinks or sugary food and drinks.

q: What are some other ways to prevent recurring UTIs?
a: If you keep getting bladder infections (cystitis), taking D-mannose or cranberry products every day may be helpful. However, it's important to speak to your doctor before taking these during pregnancy. If you're taking warfarin, you should avoid cranberry products.
